en: Hey stranger! Remember me?
zh: 嘿，陌生人，你還記得我嗎？

en: I’m that guy you used to know, what’s his name, the writer dude, the one with the funny-sounding disease.
zh: 我得了一種聽上去很有趣的病，你以前認識我，作家老兄，不過叫什麼來著？

en: This is day ten of the Madness Journal. Sorry it’s not so regular, but life and the things that go along with it (that you’ll soon start to forget) keep getting in the way.
zh: 這是「狂人日記」的第十天，對不起，寫得不太有規律，但生活不也是這樣毫無規律地進行著嗎（不過你會很快忘記的）？

en: Actually, enough joking around. How are you? Seriously, Jerry, you doing okay?
zh: 開玩笑的，傑瑞，說正經的，你還好嗎？

en: Hopefully things aren’t too messed up. Hopefully the journal isn’t having a negative effect on you.
zh: 但願事情還沒有一團糟，希望日記不會給你帶來什麼麻煩。

en: It may be a map back to the person you once were, but it’s also serving as a reminder to what you’ve lost.
zh: 你可以在這裏按圖索驥地找回從前的你，也能時時提醒你失去了什麼。

en: Day ten and you feel like you’ve always felt. Fit. Healthy.
zh: 第十天了，你的感受一如既往，身體健康依舊，只是有點兒累罷了。

en: A little tired, maybe, but that’s all. You actually went out to dinner last night with Sandra —in all your years since being married, you’ve always had at least one date night every month—and you both spoke about books, and movies, what was happening in the news, what some of your friends were up to.
zh: 昨晚，你與桑德拉一同外出吃了頓晚飯——結婚多年，你們仍舊保持著每個月的某晚出去約會的習慣——你們倆談論圖書、電影、新聞、朋友。

en: It was really nice to just talk about something other than the insanity bomb waiting to detonate at some point in the future.
zh: 有事兒可談挺好的，總比等著某個隱秘的炸彈爆炸好。

en: The counselor came around this afternoon. Her name is Beverly, and her breasts were so huge they were resting on her knees when she sat down, and were almost resting on her knees even when she was standing.
zh: 今天下午，心理諮詢師過來了，她叫貝弗莉，乳|房大得不管站著還是坐著都能垂到膝蓋上。

en: She’s in her fifties now, but by the time she’s sixty they’ll surely have snapped her spine in half.
zh: 她現在五十多歲了，等到六十歲時，她的一對乳|房能把她的脊椎扯成兩半。

en: Sandra told me afterwards that she reminded her of one of our professors back at university, a Miss Malady, who she used to call Miss Catlady, and as soon as she said it you saw the resemblance.
zh: 後來，桑德拉告訴我，說貝弗莉讓她想起了我們的大學教授馬拉迪小姐，她常常叫她貓女郎。話一出口，我就想到她們倆的相似之處。

en: She came around and we were right, buddy—out came the five stages of dementia, or grief.
zh: 她走過來說，老兄，我們正在經歷痴呆症或憂鬱症的五個階段。

en: Stage one—denial.
zh: 第一階段：否認。

en: She pointed out you had been in denial since the first time you forgot Sandra’s name and put it down to the drinks.
zh: 她說你第一次忘記桑德拉的名字時，一直在矢口否認，並將其歸咎於酗酒。

en: She said you’re still going to be in a stage of denial for a while—it’s the shock, you see.
zh: 她說，現在你仍舊停留在這一階段，你看，你還是對現狀難以置信。

en: Are you reading this now, still refusing to believe what’s happened?
zh: 但是不是仍然不敢相信發生的一切？

en: It’s hard to know how to feel about that. Sad, in some ways, but in others it’s comforting to think of you staying strong, of staying steadfast and refusing to allow the Dark Tomorrow that is on its way to arrive.
zh: 別人的確很難感同身受，一想到這一點就讓人感到悲哀，不過，考慮到你仍舊身體壯實、意志堅定，仍舊抵觸黑暗的明天而不妥協，這還是令人欣慰的。

en: Stage two—anger.
zh: 第二階段——憤怒。

en: You’re going to be snapping at people and saying mean things.
zh: 你會沖人大吼大叫，說些刻薄惡毒的話。

en: You thought earlier it might be useful to push Sandra away—useful for her—but after today, after listening to Beverly, well, you’re as scared as ever.
zh: 你剛還在想讓桑德拉走開會對她有好處，不過今天聽完了貝弗莉的話后，你的害怕不減當初。

en: There are drugs to make you more comfortable— us more comfortable—and she said this journal was a good idea and asked if Sandra could read it because it might help chart the progression.
zh: 開些葯可以緩解你的不適，也可以讓我們安心。寫寫日記也是個好主意，你可以讓桑德拉也讀一讀，這樣能幫你們掌握疾病的進展情況。你說你會考慮，但你本該說不行的。

en: So denial and anger are the two things you’re going through now. Bargaining is next. Not sure who to bargain with, really. Who do you have to sell your soul to around here to get a clean bill of health?
zh: 因此，否認和憤怒是你眼下正在經歷的兩階段，下一階段是「討價還價」，不過你並不知道要跟誰討價還價，你能向誰出賣靈魂來換取一份健康證明呢？

en: It’s possible within the next few weeks you’ll end up telling Doctor Goodstory there must be something, begging for anything that money can buy, just get you into the next clinical trial that is showing some kind of promise, doesn’t have to be the next sure thing—at this point you’d take the next maybe thing.
zh: 也許幾個星期以後，你最終會告訴古德斯特里醫生，只要可以，即便用錢，就讓你做臨床試驗，哪怕不一定能完全治愈，但起碼也有一絲希望。

en: You’d sell the house and use the money to bribe your way into any kind of trial at this point—who wouldn’t?
zh: 你可以賣掉房子，用這筆錢換來一場臨床試驗。誰都會這麼做的，不是嗎？

en: You told Beverly it felt like The Very Hungry Caterpillar was about to make its way through your mind, leaving holes everywhere it went as it gorged itself on memories before turning into a butterfly and taking flight.
zh: 你告訴貝弗莉這感覺就像飢餓的毛毛蟲鑽進你的大腦，在途中啃噬出無數個窟窿，吞食你的記憶，最後變成一隻蝴蝶，展翅而飛。

en: You told her you were starting to think of the man you’re going to become as The Jerry Replacement, a version of you that would function on different levels, and you were worried about the kind of person he would be.
zh: 你告訴她，你在想自己以後是否會變成另一個傑瑞，一個完全不同的傑瑞。你在想這個傑瑞是個什麼樣的人，他善良嗎？

en: Short tempered?
zh: 性子急嗎？

en: How many of the same qualities would you share with him?
zh: 你跟他有多少一樣的品質呢？

en: She said there would be good days and there would be bad. Take from that what you will, Future Jerry.
zh: 她說以後的日子有好有壞，未來的傑瑞，這就看你如何看待了。

en: You can’t remember what the fourth stage of grief is.
zh: 你不記得憂鬱症的第四階段是什麼了。

en: You were going to look it up online earlier, but, eye-roll, you can’t remember the password on your computer.
zh: 你之前想上網查查，但又忘了電腦的密碼，只能跟屏幕大眼瞪小眼。

en: It’ll come to you soon, no doubt, and if not Sandra will know it. She knows everything—you just don’t want her to know you can’t remember it.
zh: 你肯定會想起來的，要是想不起來的話，你還能去問桑德拉，她什麼都知道，你只是不想讓她知道你不記得了。

en: Beverly was here for three hours.
zh: 貝弗莉在這裏坐了三個小時。

en: It was a long day, and she gave you both some worst-case scenarios and some best-case scenarios.
zh: 這真是漫長的一天，她為你們倆做了最好的準備和最壞的打算。

en: It’s possible you could be in a nursing home within the next few months.
zh: 她說，在未來幾個月你可能會一直住在療養院。

en: Can you believe that?
zh: 你能相信嗎？

en: A few months!
zh: 幾個月啊！

en: She stressed that was the worst case, but the fact that at forty-nine you got Alzheimer’s, well, isn’t that already worst case?
zh: 她強調這是最壞的打算。但是，你四十九歲就患上阿爾茨海默病，這難道不是最壞的情況？

en: You shook her hand when she left, and Sandra exchanged hugs with her.
zh: 她離開時，你同她握了手，桑德拉和她擁抱。

en: When she was gone, you sat down with Sandra and between you decided it was time to tell Eva.
zh: 她走以後，你和桑德拉坐了下來，商量著告訴伊娃實情。

en: She’s coming over for dinner tomorrow night. She’ll ask to pass the salt, and you’ll say sure, and by the way I’m dying.
zh: 她明天晚上會過來吃飯，她會說勞煩把鹽遞過來，你會說好的，對了，我快要死了。

en: there’s no way to tell her in a way that isn’t going to devastate her. You can imagine her sitting the same way she did with your mother, reading To Kill a Mockingbird to you, pouring a glass of water and asking you every now and then if you’re okay.
zh: 你能想象她像你母親那樣坐著，給你讀《殺死一隻知更鳥》，給你倒杯水，時不時地噓寒問暖。

en: Bad news—you don’t have a cat. It died six years ago.
zh: 壞消息：你沒有貓，它六年前就死了。

en: And his name is Jerry Grey. He is fifty years old and an Alzheimer’s patient.
zh: 他叫傑瑞·格雷，今年五十歲，患有阿爾茨海默病。

en: He is an author and not a bank robber. Vault is one of his books.
zh: 他是位作家，而不是銀行搶劫犯，《保險箱》是他寫的書。

en: This is a nursing home.
zh: 這裡是療養院。

en: This is his life.
zh: 這就是他的生活。

en: The news is so sudden he has to sit back down on the bed. There is no farmhouse. No cash. No security guards.
zh: 這個消息太突然了，他失神地坐在床上：沒有什麼農舍，沒有什麼現金，沒有什麼保安，一切都是狂想。

en: Just madness. He looks to the bedside table, but his journal isn’t there, nor is it on the bookshelf where there are other copies of his books.
zh: 他看看床頭櫃，但沒有看到日記，書架上也沒有，只堆著他的其他作品。

en: He moves to the chair by the window and looks out at the gardens and watches the sun turn shade into light one degree at a time.
zh: 他走近窗旁的椅子，眺望花園，看著陽光將陰霾驅走。

en: He can remember pieces of this morning, just small snippets. He was in Crazy Jerry Mode, which is what he sometimes calls it.
zh: 他能記住今天清晨的一些片段，現在他已經轉換到「瘋狂的傑瑞模式」，這是他自己這麼叫的。

en: He finishes getting dressed then heads out to the dining room, desperate for some lunch.
zh: 他穿好衣服，肚子因為沒吃午飯餓得慌，便向餐廳走去。

en: Eric sees him and comes over, a big smile on his face.
zh: 艾瑞克看到他走過來，臉上露出笑容。

en: “How are you feeling?”
zh: 「你覺得怎麼樣？」

en: Eric asks.
zh: 艾瑞克問。

en: “I feel . . .” Jerry says, then thinks of the best way to sum it up. With the truth, he decides. “I feel embarrassed.”
zh: 「我覺得……」傑瑞說，忽然又一時詞窮，決定照直說了，「我覺得難堪。」

en: “That’s the last thing you need to feel,” Eric says.
zh: 「你不該這麼想。」艾瑞克說。

en: A guy with a chunk of his skull caved in is being wheeled towards a window. He thinks the wheelchair guy’s name is Glen and he used to be a prison guard until his own private destiny landed him in here with the rest of them.
zh: 一個顱骨塌陷的男人坐在窗邊的輪椅上，他覺得這位坐在輪椅上的人名叫格倫，曾經是一名獄警，來到療養院是命中注定。

en: “Then why do I feel it?”
zh: 「那我為什麼會有這樣的感覺？」

en: Eric tells him he has a doctor’s appointment this afternoon, and he had forgotten—it’s the kind of thing he’d have forgotten even before he picked up his hitchhiker, a guy by the name of Dementia with a big fat capital D. “I’ve remembered,” Jerry says.
zh: 艾瑞克告訴他，今天下午和醫生有約，不過他已經忘了。即便在這個姓「痴」的痴呆症在他身體里安營紮寨之前，他也會常常忘了這種事。

en: “What about yesterday?”
zh: 「你還記得你昨天偷偷溜出去了嗎？」

en: “You wandered into town.”
zh: 「昨天怎麼了？」「你進了城。」

en: Jerry laughs.
zh: 傑瑞哈哈大笑起來，卻又戛然而止。

en: “It’s the third time over the last few months,” Eric says.
zh: 「短短几個月，你已經溜出去三次了。」艾瑞克說。

en: “The third time?”
zh: 「三次了？」

en: “Yes,” Eric says.
zh: 「是的。」艾瑞克說。

en: Jerry shakes his head. “I’m not sure about the other times, but I remember yesterday.
zh: 傑瑞搖了搖頭：「我不記得其他幾次了，

en: Not the wandering, but I remember meeting Eva at the police station. I remember walking along the beach before being brought back here.
zh: 我不記得怎麼進城的，但我記得在警局見到了伊娃，然後我們去海灘散步，接著回到了這裏。

en: I wanted to go home. I still want to go home.”
zh: 我想回家，我還是想回家。」

en: “I’m sorry, Jerry, but this is your home now.”
zh: 「我很抱歉，傑瑞，但這兒就是你的家了。」

en: “Until I get better,” Jerry says.
zh: 「等我康復這裏就不是我的家了。」傑瑞說。

en: “Until then,” Eric says, and smiles.
zh: 「那就等你康復吧。」艾瑞克笑了笑，「吃午飯吧。」

en: Jerry eats his lunch by the window, where he can look out at the trees bordering the ground. They go for miles in most directions. There are lots of roses and daffodils everywhere, and some of the folks who wander the corridors of the nursing home are pulling weeds and soaking up the spring sun.
zh: 傑瑞在窗旁吃飯，在這裏他可以看到綿延不止的樹林，四處綻放著玫瑰和水仙。

en: He knows it’s his first book, but it’s been so long since he’s read it that he can’t remember the details.
zh: 他知道這是他寫的第一本書，即便讀了多遍也還是不記得細節。

en: He sits in the chair with his feet up on the chair opposite and starts reading, and realizes it’s not just the details he’s forgotten, but most of the entire story.
zh: 他坐在椅子上，雙腳搭在對面另一把椅子上，又一次重讀。他發現自己不只是忘了細節，連情節都忘得差不多了。

en: He’s thirty pages in when Eric comes and gets him, telling him his doctor has arrived, then leads him to an examination room.
zh: 他一直讀到了三十頁，這時艾瑞克進門說醫生已經到了，要帶他到檢查室。

en: He recognizes the doctor but can’t remember his name.
zh: 他認識醫生，但想不起他的名字了。

en: The doctor is a good ten years older than him with teeth so perfect Jerry suspects he may actually be a dentist, then realizes it’d make more sense that the doctor trades medical services with a dentist, swapping the painkillers and the occasional backyard surgery for fillings and root canals.
zh: 醫生比他年長十歲，牙齒潔白整齊，不由得讓傑瑞懷疑他是個牙醫，隨後他覺得，這個醫生應該是常常和牙醫有些來往，換一些止痛藥啦，補補牙啦，做牙根管手術啦，這更現實一點兒。

en: The doctor asks how he’s doing, and Jerry isn’t sure what the doctor is really expecting to hear, so he tells him he’s doing fine.
zh: 醫生問他感覺怎麼樣，傑瑞不知道醫生想聽到什麼，所以只好告訴他很好。

en: “Do you remember who I am?”
zh: 「你還記得我是誰嗎？」

en: “My doctor,” Jerry says.
zh: 「我的醫生。」傑瑞說。

en: “Can you remember my name?”
zh: 「你還記得我的名字嗎？」

en: “No.”
zh: 「記不得了。」

en: “It’s Doctor Goodstory.”
zh: 「我是古德斯特里醫生。」

en: “Why couldn’t it be Doctor Goodnews?”
zh: 「為什麼不是古德紐斯醫生？」

en: Jerry asks.
zh: 傑瑞問。

en: Doctor Goodstory smiles, then goes about taking Jerry’s blood pressure before running some memory tests with him, some things Jerry can answer and some things he can’t, then Goodstory asks him some logic questions, and again he can answer some and not others.
zh: 古德斯特里醫生笑了笑，然後為傑瑞測量血壓、測試記憶，有些傑瑞還能回答，有些不能。後來，古德斯特里醫生又問他一些邏輯問題，他還是只能答上一些，其他的答不來。

en: “I hear you had quite the adventure yesterday,” he says.
zh: 「我聽說你昨天幹了件很冒險的事兒。」他說。

en: “I can remember bits and pieces,” Jerry says.
zh: 「我記得一些零星的片段。」傑瑞說，「我記得伊娃帶我去海邊了。」

en: “We’ve been charting the progression of the disease, Jerry,” Goodstory says.
zh: 「我們一直在關注疾病的進展情況，傑瑞。」

en: “It can vary from day to day, some days you are extremely lucid, other days you’re never fully aware of where you are, or even who you are.
zh: 古德斯特里醫生說，「它無時無刻不在變化，有些時候你頭腦非常清醒，有些時候你完全不知道自己在哪兒，也不知道自己是誰。

en: Like I say, things vary, but there are consistent themes to your overall state. One of those themes is that often, when you wake up, you wake up believing you’re back in your old life. The sense that everything is as it used to be stays with you sometimes only for a few minutes, sometimes for a few hours. It’s as though you regress to a certain time in your life.
zh: 表現形式雖各不相同，但總體上有一點共通之處：那就是當你醒來時，你總是覺得自己回到了以前的生活，回到了過去的某個片段當中，就像這些已經逝去的一直縈繞在你心頭，有時就短短几分鐘，有時可以維持幾個小時。

en: This morning, for example, I’m told you woke up believing you were on tour.
zh: 比如說，今天上午有人告訴我你醒來后以為自己在旅行途中。

en: Mostly you revert back to a time over the last few years, though on occasion back to when you were much younger. There are days where you have absolutely no idea what is going on, where you can’t even feed yourself.
zh: 大多數情況下你會退回到幾年前的某段時光，偶爾也會回到更年輕時的時候，極少數情況下你會處在混沌無知的狀態，連吃飯都不會。

en: These days are rare, but they do happen and, sadly, will begin to happen even more.”
zh: 這種情況很罕見，但的確有。悲哀的是，以後這種情況會經常發生。」

en: Jerry looks at his hands as Goodstory talks to him.
zh: 古德斯特里醫生在跟傑瑞說話時，傑瑞一直注視著自己的雙手。

en: He feels so silly.
zh: 他覺得自己是個傻瓜。

en: “Even at your best now there are still so many things you’ve forgotten,” Goodstory says.
zh: 「即使此刻你處在最佳的狀態，你還是會忘掉許多東西。」古德斯特里醫生說，「你抑制住了記憶。」

en: “What kind of memories?”
zh: 「什麼樣的記憶？」

en: “Just memories.
zh: 「就是記憶。

en: We’ll ask you something that you’ll have no idea about. Some things will come back to you, but there are things that refuse to.
zh: 我們會問一些你不知道的事情，有些你會想起來，有些就想不起來。

en: Mornings are the hardest. Once you become aware, then often you become very lucid, very aware, just like now. I’ve had conversations where I’m talking to you and I can see the words just falling off you, and I’ve had conversations where you’re almost like the man you used to be.
zh: 早晨的情況最糟，不過一旦你意識到自己的現狀，你的頭腦就會變得比較清晰，就像現在一樣，跟你說話時我發現你妙語連珠，和原來的你別無二致。

en: The theme of struggling in the morning after waking up also extends to naps. Often you’ll take an afternoon nap, and when you wake up you’ll be confused, yet that tends to only last a few minutes. Sometimes much less than that, fifteen minutes at the most, then you become alert again.”
zh: 你通常會午睡，醒來后你的意識也會變得混沌，也會對現狀困惑不已，但往往只持續幾分鐘，有時更短，最多一刻鐘，接著你就能清醒過來。」

en: “Am I able to function in these other states?”
zh: 「遇到這種情況時我的身體狀況還正常嗎？」

en: “Sometimes quite well.
zh: 「當然正常。

en: “But you can remember being on tour years ago?”
zh: 「你能記得多年以前的旅行嗎？」

en: “But I don’t keep the memories. It’s almost as though I’m sleepwalking.”
zh: 「但我真記不得了，我好像在夢遊。」

en: “That’s as good an analogy as any,” Goodstory says.
zh: 「這是個很好的比喻。」古德斯特里說，「阿爾茨海默病就是這樣的，傑瑞。

en: It erases things, it creates, it rewrites.”
zh: 它會刪除記憶、創造記憶乃至改寫記憶。」

en: “Will I remember this conversation?”
zh: 「我會記住這次對話嗎？」

en: “I imagine you will, right up until the moment you won’t. That could be twenty-four hours. It could be a week.
zh: 「我覺得你會，但總會忘掉的，可能在二十四小時以內，可能在一個星期後。

en: You might not think about it for twenty years, then it will just seem like yesterday.”
zh: 也有可能你二十多年裡都不會想起這次對話，但想起它時會覺得恍然如昨。」

en: “Is there a crueler disease, Doctor?”
zh: 「還有比這更痛苦的疾病嗎，醫生？」

en: “Sometimes I’m not so sure there is.
zh: 「我也不太確定有沒有。

en: They really should be keeping a better eye on you here,” Goodstory adds. “It’s one of the conditions.”
zh: 他們真應該好好照顧你的，」古德斯特里補充道，「這是人們住在療養院的條件之一。」

en: When he’s gone Jerry heads out into the sun with A Christmas Murder.
zh: 醫生離開后，傑瑞拿著《聖誕節謀殺案》出來曬太陽。

en: For the next few hours all he does is read, caught up in the momentum of a killer and a cop.
zh: 他閱讀了幾個小時，沉浸在警察和殺人犯鬥智斗勇的情節中。

en: He has the feeling that theme carries over into his life as well.
zh: 他感覺這個主題延續到他的真實生活中。

en: She is somebody he used to know. An actual person. He can’t remember her real name, but she was a neighbor when he was a teenager, until she was no longer his neighbor because her ex-boyfriend killed her.
zh: 她曾是真實存在過的，他認得她，但記不得她的真實姓名了。

en: He used to have a huge crush on her—she was ten years older than him, but he fell in love with her that summer—fell in love from the opposite side of the street, too young and too nervous to ever talk to her.
zh: 十幾歲時，他們倆是鄰居，後來，她的前男友殺了她。他曾經狂熱地迷戀過她，即便她比他大十歲。那個夏天，他站在對面的街道上向她袒露心扉：他愛上了她。只是那時他還太年輕了，說起話來緊張得語無倫次。

en: He based this book on what happened to her. He used her story to write one of his own, a story he then went on to sell, a story that helped pay his mortgage, that helped give Eva a good education, a story that gave them the chance to travel the world—all things that couldn’t have been any further from Suzan’s mind when her ex-boyfriend’s hands were around her throat.
zh: 他把她當成原型，把那場謀殺當成情節寫進了這本書，然後拿去售賣，支付抵押貸款，提供伊娃一流的教育，給他們一家週遊世界的機會——當蘇姍的前男友扼住她喉嚨的時候，恐怕她永遠也想不到會有這一天。

en: Jerry remembers coming home from university that day, the police cars on his street, his parents telling him what had happened. Suzan was gone and it didn’t make sense how life could end so easily. That’s the balance, he realizes.
zh: 傑瑞還記得，那一天他從大學回家，看見街頭停著警車，他的父母告訴了他一切：蘇姍死了，生命如此脆弱，卻連一點兒預兆也沒有。

en: He decides he doesn’t ever want to read any of his books ever again, because there’s something more than just the memory of coming home and finding the police cars. There’s something else hidden in the darkness—best he stops looking.
zh: 他也不想再讀他寫的其他書了，它們不僅會讓他回想起回家時看到街頭警車的畫面，還會勾起黑暗中潛藏著的其他記憶，還是別喚醒這些記憶。
